title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
Overview of lecture 4
Looked at data analysis.

title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
Hypothesising
Research science is about coming up with hypotheses and evaluating them.

This lecture thinking about posing and answering reserach questions.
I have this great idea - considering the data is this idea plausibly true?

title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this lecture you should:

Establish a hypothesis.
Define the Type I and Type II errors. - Define the Type I and Type II errors.
Calculate the p-value.

title: Hypothesis Testing
section: How do we know what to believe?
text:
How do we know what to believe?


What we see in the news

Is London less safe for cyclists than ten years ago?
Are x days above 30 degrees in London indicative of a warming climate?
Is London‚Äôs murder rate higher than New York?

title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
What is a hypothesis?



You have a coin.
You think it‚Äôs a fair coin.
You toss it 10 times.
It comes up heads 7 times.

title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
What question can you ask?



You have a coin.
You think it‚Äôs a fair coin.
You toss it 10 times.
It comes up heads 7 times.



Is it a fair coin? NO!
What‚Äôs the probability that it‚Äôs fair? NO!
If the coin is fair, how likely would it be to see 7 heads out of 10 flips? ALMOST!

title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
What question should you ask?



You have a coin.
You think it‚Äôs a fair coin.
You toss it 10 times.
It comes up heads 7 times.


Correct formulation:
If the coin is fair, how likely would it be to see 7 heads out of 10 flips OR AN EVEN MORE EXTREME RESULT?

title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
Step 1
Define the question
Null hypothesis ‚Äì the status quo. The alternative hypothesis ‚Äì need some evidence to verify.

title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
Step 2
Set you significance level

Decide what ‚Äútoo unlikely‚Äù means BEFORE YOU DO THE TEST.
e.g.¬†ùú∂ = 0.05 (5% significance)
This means that if we see evidence that would have less than a 5% chance of occurring if the null hypothesis is true, then we reject the null hypothesis.

title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
Step 3
Identify the evidence

Example: data collection ‚Äì i.e urine sample for pregnancy test

title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
Step 4
Calculate the p-value

The p-value is the probability of seeing the evidence, or something even more extreme, if the null hypothesis is true.

title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
Step 5
Compare p-value with hypothesis level

p-value > ùú∂ - Evidence not that unlikely. Not enough evidence to reject H0.
p-value ‚©Ω ùú∂ - Evidence very unlikely. Reject H0 and accept H1.

title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
The steps

Define the question
Set you significance level
Identify the evidence
Calculate the p-value
Compare p-value with hypothesis level

title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
Example
Cyclists in London.

title: Hypothesis Testing
text: Type I error

title: Hypothesis Testing
text: Type II error

title: Hypothesis Testing
text: Example

title: Hypothesis Testing
text: Matrix of errors

title: Hypothesis Testing
section: Understanding the literature and the context
text:
Understanding the literature and the context
Hypothesis doesn‚Äôt come out of thin air

title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
Asking ethical hypothesis questions

not making unethical assumptions in choosing the hypothesis.
Example: correlation between ethnicity and crime
Use contextual knowledge to consider correlation vs causation

title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
Correlation vs.¬†Causation
Lots of things can be correlated - but it doesn‚Äôt mean one event caused another.

title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
Aliens and taxes
Example from spurious correlations

title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
Correlation IS NOT causation
You might not know whether events are correlated, or causing each other.
The point of the hypothesis test is to test your idea ‚Äì but use your contextual understanding to come up with plausible (and ethical) initial questions

title: Hypothesis Testing
section: The point of the scientific method
text:
The point of the scientific method
The process of coming up with a question, testing, iterating.

title: Hypothesis Testing
text: Parametric vs.¬†Non-parametric tests

title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
Parametric Tests

Evaluate hypothesis for specific parameters
Typically have assumptions about the distribution - e.g.¬†assumed normal distribution

title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
Non-parametric Tests

Evaluate hypotheis for entire population distirbution
Typcially less assumptions on the ditribution

title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
How many tails
Tests can be one-tailed or two-tailed.

title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
T-test
Assumes the data is normally distributed.

title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
T-test example
What is the probability of someone age 15 being a student on CASA007?
The probability is very small so we reject.

title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
Regression T-tests
Is the gradient non-zero?
This indicates a correlation between the two variables.
‚Ä¶
This will be covered further in lecture X on linear regression.

title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
Mean comparison t-test
Compares the mean of two distributions.

title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
Kolmogorov-Smirnov test

Compares two probability distributions
Can be used to test whether an observed sameple came from a given distribution
Or to test whether two samples both came from the same distribution

title: Hypothesis Testing
text:
Kernel density estimate

Used to generate a smooth PDF for a random variable dataset.
Think of it as getting a smooth function to describe a histogram of data.
There are no assumptions about the prior distribution

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #1
text:
Understanding and describing data

Quantitative research is the process of collecting and analysing numerical data to describe, model, and predict variables of interest.
Garbage in, garbage out.


This lecture focuses on understanding and describing data.

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #1
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this lecture you should:

Understand basic data types;
Consider how to summarise and represent data.

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #1
text:
Four levels of measurements




Nominal
Ordinal
Interval
Ratio




Categorizes and labels variables
‚úî
‚úî
‚úî
‚úî


Ranks categories in order

‚úî
‚úî
‚úî


Has known, equal intervals


‚úî
‚úî


Has a true or meaningful zero



‚úî




Developed by psychologist Stanley Smith Stevens (1906 - 1973)

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #1
text:
Nominal

Differentiates items based only on names; no order between them.
Also called categorical data
Example: colour, gender, country names
What can be said about them?

Equality: ‚Äòapple‚Äô is not ‚Äòpear‚Äô, ‚Äòapple‚Äô is ‚Äòapple‚Äô
Mode: the most common item

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #1
text:
Ordinal

Allow for rank order, but not the relative degree of difference
Example: measurement of opinions

completely agree
mostly agree
neither degree nor disagree
mostly disagree
completely disagree

What can be said about them?

‚úÖ Equality; mode
‚úÖ Median: middle-ranked item
‚ùå Differences between two levels; arithmetic mean

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #1
text:
Interval

Allow for degree of difference between items, but not the ratio
The zero value is arbitrary
Example: Celsius temperature

Definition: define 0¬∞C & 100¬∞C, and then separate them into 100 intervals.
Depends on altitude/elevation

What can be said about them?

‚úÖ equality, mode, median
‚úÖ addition, arithmetic mean
‚ùå ratio (100¬∞C is NOT twice 50¬∞C)

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #1
text:
Interval

Another example: longtitude & latitude coordinates
The coordinate of 8 is twice as far as that of 4? ‚ùå

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #1
text:
Ratio

Allow for ratio between items
The zero value is unique and non-arbitrary.
Example: mass, length, energy
What can be said about them?

‚úÖ Equality, mode, median, arithmetic mean
‚úÖ Ratio (2kg is twice as heavy as 1kg)

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #1
text:
Notes

‚ÄòEncoding‚Äô does not change the nature of a measurement.
Gender variable (male, female, others) is NOMINAL.
If this variable is encodeded {male:0, female:1, others:2}, is it NOMINAL, or INTERVAL?

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #1
text:
Another categorisation: numerical vs.¬†categorical








Type
Category
Notes




Quantitative (numerical) data
Discrete data
Only in whole numbers, e.g. number of staffs



Continuous data
e.g. temperature, 23¬∞C, 23.4¬∞C


Qualitative (categorical) data
Nominal
Same as nominal in ‚ÄòLevels of measurement‚Äô



Ordinal
See above

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #1
text:
Quiz time

Mentimeter quiz

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #1
text:
Key metrics



Quantity
The middle
The spread

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #1
text:
US city population



Quantity: 282 values
The middle: Mean 302869.3
The middle: Median 167744.5 (Very different from mean)
The middle: Mode 106433 (Useful? ‚ùå)
Should use mean or median? median is better than mean, as data is unlikely normal distributed

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #1
Exploratory Data Analysis #1
Exploratory Data Analysis #1
text:
Summary of key metrics


Quantity
The middle: mean, median, mode
The spread: variance, standard deviation
Visualising data is also important: BOXPLOT!
Please check two types of SPECIAL VALUES before computing these metrics.

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #1
text:
FT visual vocabulary

https://ft-interactive.github.io/visual-vocabulary/

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #1
text:
Boxplot for a dataset

Showing distribution of a dataset

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #1
text: Boxplot for comparing multiple datasets

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #1
text:
When boxplot fails?

When there are lots of ‚Äòoutliers‚Äô in the data
What are ‚ÄòOutliers‚Äô?

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #1
text:
Null values

Representing the absence of data or an unknow value
Different from zero or a blank space
Null values should be excluded before computing mean or std

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #1
text:
Null island in geography

long=0, lat=0. Not even an island!
It became famous because some software assigned ‚Äú0,0‚Äù for long-lat when location is missing
Many events were mapped to this one, including lots on Strava
Source: wikipedia.org

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #1
text:
Outliers

A data point that differs significantly from other observations
There are three types of outliers
Please explain the rationale for removing any identified outliers, including the criteria and methods used

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #1
text:
Outliers








Type
Source
Handling




Error Outliers
From mistakes in data collection/entry/measurement, e.g.¬†a temperature sensor reading 500‚ÄØ¬∞C
Should be corrected or removed


Irregular Pattern Outliers




Influential Outliers

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #1
text:
Outliers








Type
Source
Handling




Error Outliers




Irregular Pattern Outliers
Genuinely occur, but do not follow general pattern or relationship in the dataset, e.g.¬†sudden spikes in sales in Black Friday
They might indicate unusual events or anomalies worth investigating. If the purpose is to study overall pattern, they should be removed


Influential Outliers

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #1
text:
Outliers








Type
Source
Handling




Error Outliers




Irregular Pattern Outliers




Influential Outliers
Appear extreme but are integral to the underlying pattern or model, e.g.¬†NYC in US city population data
Should keep them, as removing them could distort the analysis or overlook important features of the data

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #1
text: Detecting outlier: interquartile range (IQR)

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #1
text:
Quiz: which type of outliers?

error vs.¬†irregular pattern vs.¬†influential


In building height data, 10-storey building with 1m height
In gender ratios of countries data, Vatican City with gender ratio of 7:1
In UK city GDP data, GDP of Greater London

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #1
text:
Summary: describing a dataset

Key metrics
Null values and outliers (and handle them!)
Visualising data

title: Welcome
text:
The Quantitative Methods (QM) module is a compulsory element of CASA‚Äôs MSc/MRes USS programmes and is intended provide an introduction to quantitative methods for all students.
As data becomes central to decision-making across all sectors, the ability to move beyond simple description to robust and evidence-based analysis is essential for researchers and practitioners in geography and urban studies. Making sense of the complex patterns that define our world requires a firm understanding of the language of data. This module provides the essential grammar for that language and aims to equip students with the foundational quantitative skills needed to describe data, build models, and derive meaningful insights from numerical evidence.
To achieve this, the module is structured progressively across three core sections. The first section establishes the fundamental toolkit for quantitative analysts. Beginning with Exploratory Data Analysis, students will learn how to visualise, summarise, and critically interrogate datasets. This is followed by a rigorous grounding in the principles of statistical inference through hypothesis testing, and an introduction to the linear algebra that provides the mathematical architecture for many of the models used in modern data science.
The second section builds upon this foundation to explore the core of statistical modelling: understanding and quantifying relationships between variables. Students will progress from measuring correlations to building sophisticated regression models. The curriculum covers the workhorse of social science, the Generalised Linear Model (GLM), before advancing to Multilevel Models, a critical technique for handling the nested and hierarchical data that is common in geographical and social research.
The final section of the course introduces advanced techniques for uncovering hidden structures within complex, high-dimensional datasets. Students will learn methods for dimensionality reduction to simplify complexity without losing vital information, and clustering analysis to identify natural groupings and patterns in data.
Therefore, this module guides students on a complete analytical journey, from foundational principles to the application of advanced modelling techniques. It serves as a vital prerequisite for more specialised analytical modules and is essential for students wishing to undertake quantitative geospatial research. Ultimately, this module will provide quantitative skills that are in high demand across public, private, and academic sectors.

title: Welcome
text:
Acknowledgements
We really appreciate the support from various people:

Jon for setting up this wonderful CASA-themed quarto template.
Ollie and Andy for inspiring us to pursue a Quarto-based module website.

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #2
text:
Overview of lecture 1
Looked at data analysis. Different types of data.

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #2
text:
First things first
Exploratory data analysis is the first step of any data science project

link to scientific process and how we iterate over ideas and concepts

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #2
text:
Introducing statistical concepts
This lecture looking at statistical concepts.
Data science is about using ideas from statistics to describe large datasets
Here looking to describe numerical data ‚Äì focus on probability distributions.

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #2
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this lecture you should:

Evaluate whether a dataset is representative.
Define the probability density function.
Identify common probability distributions.

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #2
section: What is the likelihood of events occuring?
text:
What is the likelihood of events occuring?

What is the probability of someone in this lecture theatre being over 6ft?
Need to first understand the distribution of heights.


This week thinking about the distribution of data.
Next week, thinking about formulating and answering the research question.

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #2
text:
The dream vs reality
Ideally, we would like all the relevant data ‚Äì but in reality normally have a subset

It would be great if I knew the height of every adult in the UK, but unrealistic to collect ‚Äì however maybe I could collect all adults at UCL.

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #2
text:
Approximating
Expect what happens in the sample to approximate what happens in the whole population.

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #2
text:
Bias
It‚Äôs important to understand if your dataset truly representative or is it susceptible to bias?

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #2
text:
Cognitive bias
Systematic patterns in how we think about, and perceive, the world.


We all have cognitive biases.
These can impact our research, in particular dataset collection, selection and processing.

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #2
text:
Why is this important?
If we‚Äôre not careful we can propagate bias to the reserach, and hence results.
This can lead to incorrect conclusions.

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #2
text:
Types of bias
Examples of dataset bias include historical bias and selection bias.

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #2
text:
Historical bias
Reflects existing, real world, inequalities
Examples:

Police profiling
Hungry judges

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #2
text:
Selection bias
When the sample chosen doesn‚Äôt represent the whole population of interest
This can be due to not having an adequately random sample.
Example:

The health of people in hospital is worse than the general population.

Or self-selection bias, where the people who contribute to the data exhibit specific attributes.
Example:

WEIRD study.

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #2
section: Can data ever be truly representative?
text:
Can data ever be truly representative?
Probably not.
##¬†Failing that

Acknowledge our biases!

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #2
text:
Uniquely described by two equations
Mean:
\[\begin{align}
E[x]
\end{align}\]
Standard deviation:
\[\begin{align}
E[x]
\end{align}\]

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #2
text:
and a probability distribution function
Probability density function (PDF) describes the likelihood of different outcomes for a random variable
The PDF of the normal distribution is:
\[\begin{align}
E[x]
\end{align}\]

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #2
text:
Key features

Characteristic size (all data points close to the mean): symmetric and single peak
Data is equally likely to be larger or smaller than average (symmetric): Smooth tails on both sides
Data is continuous (it is something you measure not something you count)

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #2
text:
Sampling distributions
Note importance of sampling distributions.
In the case of the normal distribution: Std represented by œÉ vs std represented by œÉ/‚àön

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #2
text: Example: distance to school

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #2
text:
Not everything is normal
Many real world datasets are approximately normally distributed.
But not all, things might not have a characteristic size, or not continuous, or not symmetric

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #2
text: Continous vs.¬†Discrete

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #2
section: Back to the probability density function
text:
Back to the probability density function
Why it‚Äôs useful ‚Äì see next week, allows us to evaluate the probability of events, and hence evaluate hypotheses

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #2
text:
Sampling distributions
Specific for different probability distributions (/n)

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #2
text:
Skewed and long tails
In reality, few things are actually normal. Anscombe‚Äôs quartet

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #2
text:
Coin toss

If I flip a coin 10 times, how often can I expect to get at least 7 heads?
Describes the frequency of successes in a test with 2 outcomes

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #2
text:
Death by horse kicks



It‚Äôs 1894.
You‚Äôre the statistician Ladislaus Bortkiewicz.
And you‚Äôre wondering,
How many soldiers in the Prussian army have been killed by horse kicks?

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #2
text:
Measuring rare events

Imagine a situation where certain rare events (like arrival of mail) can occur in an independent fashion.
The Poisson distribution estimates how many such events are expected within a time interval
Fixed interval (e.g.¬†one minute)
Fixed rate of events (Œª) (e.g.¬†4 cars per minute, Œª = 4)
Events occur independently.
Poisson Distribution gives the probability of k events.

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #2
text: Probability density function

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #2
text:
Exponentials
If the Poisson measures the probability of x events within a time period, then the Exponential measures how long we are likely to wait between events.

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #2
text:
At it like rabbits


Rapid growth of rabbit populations

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #2
text:
Estimating rabbit populations
Allows us to answer questions like: ‚Äúhow many rabbits at t=10?‚Äù
Answering questions like ‚ÄúOr when will the rabbit population=250?‚Äù
This is easier said than done ‚Äì the best way is to invert the equation ‚Äì this requires

title: Exploratory Data Analysis #2
text:
Logarithms

It is an inverse operation. Multiply and divide are inverse operations of one another (they reverse the process)
